Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Traineeship (IGERT) project at Rutgers University and partner Princeton University will establish an interdisciplinary graduate education, research, and training program focused upon scientific, technical, and policy issues related to sustainable and affordable clean energy technologies, emphasizing innovations in nanotechnology. This IGERT project will develop and implement a new interdisciplinary curriculum, Nanotechnology for Clean Energy, featuring novel courses in fundamental (nanoscale) materials science, physics, chemistry, and electrical engineering with specific applications to energy technology development. Graduate trainees will apply this innovative training in a dynamic educational exchange program with select African institutions, promoting development of their global awareness and understanding of challenges involved in scientific and economic development in the developing world. The three objectives of the African international component of this project are: (i) provide IGERT trainees with realistic perspectives of the challenges of energy generation and storage for communities located far from the grid; (ii) foster face-to-face and cyber-enabled exchanges; and (iii), encourage U.S. students, particularly those from underrepresented populations, to enter science and engineering fields to work on critical, real-world problems of relevance to developing countries. Talented undergraduates from underrepresented groups will be aggressively recruited from minority-serving institutions, including students participating in the Research in Science and Engineering Program and the Bridge to the Doctorate Program at Rutgers, designed to prepare students for the rigors of an interdisciplinary Ph.D. program. This IGERT project will help promote development of a diverse, globally aware, and scientifically capable workforce trained in nanotechnology and international development issues, and will also involve students in close interactions with national laboratories and industry partners to translate scientific results into usable and commercially-viable technologies to address real-world energy needs. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This integrated graduate training and research project has had a tremendous impact on creation of a new dynamic in graduate education in the Schools of Engineering and Arts and Sciences at Rutgers. Specificially, in implementing cross-disciplnary curriculum and breaking down boundaries between engineering, physics, chemistry, policy, and business schools. This new way trainingn graduate students is collaborative and provides a broad set of skills to prepare them for careers in academia, industry, policy, and/or business. We aim to continue this model. Above 50 graduate students were positively impacted by the program and benefitted from its initiatives,

The scientific theme of the program was Nanotechnology for Clean energy. To this end, the program has been enormously successful in deveoping new knowledge related to materials for energy storage (see highlight 1), efficient generation of hydrogen using inexpensive catalysts (see highlight 2), and development of new solar cell designs (see highlight 3). The research has led to over 200 scientific publications, numerous presentations at major conferences, and several intellectual property disclosures. The output of the students and faculty was tremendous.

A primary objective of this program was to creat and widen the diversity pipeline. To this end, we recruited graduate students from minority serving institutions. Nearly half of the students were women and approximately one fifth were from under represented groups. We also worked with local schools to engage K - 12 students (see highlight 4) in their classrooms as well as at Rutgers University. We were heavily involved with the Rutgers RISE program which recruits 50 UG interns every summer for STEM research. All RISE students are from under represented groups. Our IGERT program mentored, hosted, and recruited many of the RISE interns. 

Another key component of the program was the creation of a dynamic exchnage program with sub-Saharan African Universities. We signed MOUs with half dozen African institutions and received more than 25 visitors for short and long term visits. The involvement of African scholars in the program added a unique perspective to the program and provided a sense of urgency in developing clean energy technologies for rural African communities. Prof. Garfunkel, the coordinator of Africa activities, also organized the last two Africa MRS Meetings. Numerous IGERT trainees visited Victoria Falls Zimbabwe and Addis Adaba, Ethiopia for the AMRS 2012 and 2014 Meetings.
